title: Scrum Flashcards: Artifacts, Misconceptions, and Exam Prep
description: Flashcards covering Scrum artifacts, common misconceptions, and Professional Scrum Master (PSM) exam preparation

cards.front: What happens to partially done work?
cards.back: It's not included in the Increment and returns to the Product Backlog.

cards.front: Can the Definition of Done differ by team?
cards.back: Yes, but it should be consistent within a team.

cards.front: Can the Product Backlog be empty?
cards.back: Technically yes, but it would suggest no future work or unclear vision.

cards.front: Who creates Product Backlog items?
cards.back: Anyone can suggest them, but the Product Owner manages them.

cards.front: What's the benefit of having a visible Sprint Backlog?
cards.back: Transparency for tracking daily progress toward the Sprint Goal.

cards.front: Can Scrum be used in non-software projects?
cards.back: Yes, it's a general-purpose framework.

cards.front: Is burndown chart required in Scrum?
cards.back: No, it's optional and not part of the core Scrum Guide.

cards.front: Is Scrum predictive or adaptive?
cards.back: Adaptive; it's based on empiricism.

cards.front: Can multiple Scrum Teams share one Product Backlog?
cards.back: Yes, for the same product.

cards.front: Is the Scrum Master a project manager?
cards.back: No, their role is to support Scrum implementation and team growth.

cards.front: Can the team change the Sprint Goal mid-Sprint?
cards.back: Only if the Sprint is canceled.

cards.front: Can a Definition of Done include regulatory requirements?
cards.back: Yes, and it should.

cards.front: Who's responsible for ROI in Scrum?
cards.back: The Product Owner.

cards.front: Can Scrum be combined with Kanban?
cards.back: Yes, it's called Scrum with Kanban (or Scrumban).

cards.front: Should Product Backlog items be estimated?
cards.back: Estimation is common but not required by Scrum itself.

cards.front: What mindset does Scrum encourage in teams?
cards.back: Empirical, cross-functional, and self-managing.

cards.front: What should you do if you don't understand a question on the PSM exam?
cards.back: Flag it and return later—don't waste too much time.

cards.front: How should you approach tricky "select all that apply" questions?
cards.back: Only select answers that are fully correct and supported by the Scrum Guide.

cards.front: What's the best way to prepare for PSM I?
cards.back: Study the Scrum Guide, take practice exams, and understand real-world application.

cards.front: Is there partial credit for multi-select answers on the PSM I?
cards.back: No, you must select all correct answers to get credit.

cards.front: How many questions are on the PSM I exam?
cards.back: 80 questions.

cards.front: What's the passing score for PSM I?
How long is the PSM I exam?
cards.back: 60 minutes.

cards.front: Is the PSM I exam open book?
cards.back: No, it's a closed-book assessment.

cards.front: Should you memorize the Scrum Guide word for word?
cards.back: Not necessarily, but understand it deeply—concepts matter more than wording.
